intro: Pseudognaphalium coquimbense, commonly known as the Coquimbo goldenweed, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Chile. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showing adaptations to dry conditions such as reduced leaf size and dense foliage. Its flowers are usually yellow or golden, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Pseudognaphalium coquimbense is often found in coastal areas and can thrive in sandy or gravelly soils.
